Sonny Angara said on Thursday that Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez III offered the trade when some senators and House leaders met with President Duterte in Malaca\u00f1ang on Aug. 1.\n\n\"Secretary Dominguez was saying they were willing to trade the (tax on) sugar-sweetened beverages, but we pass in full the excise tax on fuel,\" Angara told reporters.\n\nAngara is chair of the committee on ways and means, which is looking into Malaca\u00f1ang's proposed comprehensive tax reform package.\n\nThe tax reform package seeks to lower personal income tax rates, expand the value-added tax base, raise excise taxes on oil products and automobiles, impose an excise tax on sugar-sweetened beverages, and ease the rates of estate and donor's taxes.\n\nAngara said he was unable to clarify with Dominguez whether the finance secretary meant the P6 per liter additional tax on oil products or the House of Representatives' version of \"3-2-1.\"\n\nTweaking tax package\n\nHe said Dominguez proposed the trade as a \"discussion point\" as the Senate scrutinized the comprehensive tax package, which many senators fear would have inflationary effects and affect many industries.\n\nThe Aug. 1 meeting was where senators found Mr. Duterte open to tweaking the comprehensive tax reform package, a departure from his call for the Senate to pass the bill in full in his State of the Nation Address on July 24.\n\nThe House has already approved the excise tax on oil products, imposing a 3-2-1 schedule, or P3 per liter in the first year, P2 in the second and P1 in the third.\n\nAngara said he told Dominguez that the Senate would study the proposal, noting that there was the possibility that the proposed higher tax on fuel could still be reduced.\n\n\"We're still studying the implications,\" said Angara, who held on Thursday the last of two hearings for the Tax Reform for Acceleration and Inclusion bills.\n\nAngara said the economic managers also seemed \"receptive\" to itemizing where proceeds of particular provisions would go in the tax package.\n\nBigger chance\n\n\"They realized that the bill has a bigger chance of being passed if people know where their money will go. Because people would complain of higher taxes when these are being spent on insignificant projects,\" Angara said.\n\nAngara said his committee aimed to submit the Senate version of the comprehensive tax package by September.\n\nThe Senate has done away with its plan to convene a committee of the whole to grill economic managers on the comprehensive tax reform package, as senators were meeting with them, according to Angara.\n\nHe earlier said he found somewhat high the proposed P10 per liter tax on sugar-sweetened beverages. {"sim": 0.8784313797950745, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370267", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9783930", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "caribbeannewsnow.com", "title": "caribbeannewsnow.com", "id": "5985"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Miami"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": null, "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.caribbeannewsnow.com/headline-UPDATE%3A-Tropical-Storm-Harvey-forms%2C-warnings-issued-35370.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:58:00", "title": "UPDATE: Tropical Storm Harvey forms, warnings issued", "uri": "711133612", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:58:00Z", "time": "21:58:00", "body": "MIAMI, USA -- A US Air Force Reserve Hurricane Hunter aircraft found that the tropical system moving into the Eastern Caribbean had become Tropical Storm Harvey on Thursday afternoon. A tropical storm warning has been issued for Martinique, Saint Lucia, Barbados and St Vincent and the Grenadines. A tropical storm watch is in effect for Dominica.\n\nAccording to the National Hurricane Center (NHC) in Miami, at 5:00 pm on Thursday, the center of Tropical Storm Harvey was located about 250 miles (400 km) east of Barbados and about 355 miles (570 km) east of Saint Lucia, moving toward the west near 18 mph (30 km/h). This motion is expected to continue for the next couple of days.\n\nOn the forecast track, Harvey should move through the Windward Islands and into the eastern Caribbean Sea on Friday. Reports from the Hurricane Hunter Aircraft indicated that maximum sustained winds are near 40 mph (65 km/h) with higher gusts. Slow strengthening is possible during the next 48 hours. Tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 35 miles (55 km) to the north of the centre.\n\nTropical storm conditions are expected to first reach the Lesser Antilles within the warning area by early Friday, making outside preparations difficult or dangerous. Tropical storm conditions are possible in the watch area on Friday.\n\nHarvey is expected to produce rainfall totals of 2 to 4 inches across portions of the Windward Islands from Martinique southward to Grenada. These rains could cause life-threatening flash floods and mudslides.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences", "wgt": 100, "id": 89, "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth If wind speed grows to 39 miles per hour, the National Hurricane Center it would become Tropical Storm Gert.\n\nThe Atlantic has had six named storms, including one hurricane (Franklin), so far this year. The system is expected to head north along the coast before peeling off into the Atlantic early next week.\n\nAt the moment, it appears this alleyway will set up far enough east that the US would 5636, retained Malacanang's excise tax proposal on oil products but suggested that this be divided into P3.00, P2.00 and P1.00 over three years.\n\nAngara said several senators still considered the rates \"too\" high and suggested a different scheme to lessen the impact of the increase.\n\nWhile it will retain the P6.00 excise tax on diesel, the Senate is eyeing a split of P1.00, 2.00 and P3.00 on oil products.\n\nAccording to Dominguez, Pimentel's bill is expected to gain about P167 billion in net revenues, higher than the P134 billion in the version approved by the House of Representatives.\n\nThe P10-per-liter excise tax on sugar-sweetened drinks is expected to generate P47 billion in the first year of implementation.\n\nUnder House Bill No. 5636, or the Tax Reform for Likely to Stay East of the Carolinas Early Next Week", "uri": "708667846", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T01:38:00Z", "time": "01:38:00", "body": "A cold front along the East Coast should keep the depression away from the eastern seaboard.\n\nTropical Depression Eight has formed a few hundred miles northeast of the Bahamas, and it could pick up surf along the East Coast.\n\nPreviously dubbed Invest 99L, this system has become a little better defined and the shower and thunderstorm activity has increased, allowing the upgrade to Tropical Depression Eight.\n\nThe environment around this storm is improving, with less wind shear and dry air, but these still not ideal conditions should keep Tropical Depression Eight from getting too strong.\n\nThat said, environmental conditions are expected to be good enough to allow Eight to become a tropical storm on Sunday, and it should strengthen as it moves northward in the western Atlantic.\n\nThe next named storm that forms in the Atlantic will be Gert.\n\nThis system will begin to turn more to the north on Sunday east of the U.S. That is because it will be sandwiched between the western periphery of high pressure in the central Atlantic and an incoming cold front across the eastern U.S.\n\nTropical Depression Eight will take the alleyway in between those large-scale weather systems.\n\nAt the moment, it appears this alleyway will set up far enough east that the U.S. would avoid any direct impacts, but increased surf along the East Coast is possible. A higher rip current risk is possible too.\n\nCheck back with us at weather.com for the latest on this, and everything in the tropics this hurricane season.", "date": "2017-08-13", "categories": A recent Sun Sentinel article confirmed (as of 15 minutes ago) that it has indeed become a tropical storm, that it has been given a 100 percent chance of becoming a tropical cyclone over the next two days, and that it is expected to become a hurricane by Monday morning. A tropical storm warning is now in effect for Barbados, St. Lucia, Martinique, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines, while a tropical storm watch has been issued for Dominica.\n\nTropical Storm Harvey is headed toward the Windward Islands at 18 mph and is expected to bring two to four inches of rain with it. Maximum winds are gusting up to 40 mph, forecasters said. Earlier today, the depression was 365 miles east of Barbados and 465 miles east of St Lucia and carrying maximum sustained winds near 35 miles per hour.\n\nAccording to the National Hurricane Center (NHC) in Miami, the system is expected to produce rainfall totals of 2 to 4 inches across portions of the Windward Islands from Martinique southward to Grenada, which could cause life-threatening That's enough to cause flash flooding and mud slides, according to forecasters.\n\nThe long-range forecast track has Harvey making landfall in Central America or the Yucatan Peninsula next week at near hurricane strength.\n\nIt is not expected to be a threat to the U.S.\n\nTo the east of Harvey are two other potential tropical storms in the making.\n\nThe first, which has been designated Invest 92L, was located about 900 miles east of the Leeward Islands early Friday.\n\nThis one has a path that those in Florida will need to watch, because the hurricane center shows it tracking to the northwest and into the Bahamas.\n\nThe hurricane center said Invest 92L continued to show signs of organization and raised the chances of a tropical depression forming to 70 percent.\n\nForecasters said Invest 92L will continue to track to the west-northwest, but it could encounter less favorable conditions early next week.\n\nThe other wave was located far to the east, a few hundred miles southwest of the Cabo Verde Islands.\n\nIt has a 30 percent chance of development over the next five days.\n\nMissing from the board on Friday was Hurricane Gert, which was ruled a post-tropical storm The systems are forecast to merge throughout the next two days as they move west at about 15 mph. There is a 40-percent chance of the systems developing into a tropical cyclone over the next five days and a 10-percent chance of development within 48 hours.\n\nTropical Storm Gert is expected to travel north along the coast for the next three days and then move further east into the Atlantic after Wednesday.\n\nAn advisory was issued around 4 p.m. Sunday, when the hurricane center said Gert strengthened from a tropical depression into a tropical storm. The storm is moving north-northwest at 10 mph with winds at a maximum of 40 mph, according to the advisory. Winds are expected to strengthen slowly over the next two days. As of 5 p.m. Sunday, the storm was sitting 505 miles off the west coast of Bermuda.\n\nGert is expected to be roughly halfway between Bermuda and North Carolina on Monday or Tuesday. At the time of 5 p.m. advisory there were no coastal warnings or watches in effect.\n\nThe tropical storm continues what forecasters project to be an above-average hurricane season, with between 14 and 19 named storms estimated to potentially form. The hurricane center expects Gert to take a more northward path this morning and then turn to the north-northeast tonight. That track would steer Gert away from the U.S.\n\nComputer forecast models have consistently kept Gert on that path, and confidence is on the higher side that Gert will not affect the U.S.\n\nGert had winds of 45 mph early Monday. Forecasters said it could get stronger and become a hurricane by Wednesday.\n\nHurricane force winds begin at 74 mph.\n\nFar to the east of Tropical Storm Gert is another tropical wave that's worth watching.\n\nThat storm system, which has been designated Invest 91L, is being described by the hurricane center as a large and complex area of disturbed weather.\n\nIt includes a trough of low pressure and a tropical wave. The hurricane center expects those to merge in a few days and continue to develop into what could be a tropical depression.\n\nThe probability of a depression forming has been steadily rising and was 50 percent as of Monday morning.\n\nInvest 91L is forecast to continue on a westward path at about 15 mph, which could put it close to the Lesser Antilles by the end of the work week.", "date": {"sim": 0.7333333492279053, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9286568", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "tampabay.com", "title": "Tampa Bay Times", "id": "2249"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Miami"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "http://www.tampabay.com/resources/images/dti/rendered/2017/08/gert081517_8a_19817395_8col.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.tampabay.com/news/weather/hurricanes/while-gert-strengthens-into-hurricane-forecasters-monitoring-two-more/2333799", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:31:00", "title": "While Gert strengthens into hurricane, forecasters monitoring two more systems", "uri": "709787028", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:31:00Z", "time": "13:31:00", "body": "MIAMI -- Forecasters say Gert has strengthened to become the second hurricane of the season in the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center says Gert was about 450 miles (725 kilometers) west of Bermuda early Tuesday and had maximum sustained winds of 75 mph (120 kph). The storm was moving north at 12 mph (13 kph).\n\nThe weather advisory says Gert has developed an eye and is expected to strengthen in the next 48 hours. The forecast calls for it to turn northeast and accelerate Tuesday night.\n\nSwells generated by Gert will begin to affect portions of Bermuda and the U.S. East Coast -- from North Carolina to New York -- over the next couple of days.\n\nNo coastal watches or warnings are in effect, but the hurricane center says these swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions in the region.\n\nHurricane Franklin became the first hurricane of the 2017 season in the Atlantic last week. The storm made landfall on Mexico's Gulf Coast early Thursday as a Category 1 hurricane.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are monitoring two other systems in the Atlantic.\n\nOne located more than 1,000 miles east of the Lesser Antilles, has a 20 percent chance of development over the next 48 hours and 40 percent over the next five days.\n\nThe other is further west. It is an area of low pressure located a few hundred miles west-southwest of the Cabo Verde Islands, and has a 10 percent chance of formation in the next 48 hours (20 percent over the next five The satellite imagery showed the circulation of the low pressure area was becoming better defined and that a cluster of strong convection has formed west of the center.\n\nNOAA manages the GOES series of satellites, and NASA uses the satellite data to create images and animations. The image was created by the NASA/NOAA GOES Project at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland.\n\nTropical Depression Nine (TD9) formed around 11 p.m. EDT on Aug. 17 about 365 miles east of the Barbados and 465 miles (750 km) east of St. Lucia.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center (NHC) issued a Tropical Storm Warning for Martinique, St. Lucia, Barbados, St. Vincent and the Grenadines. A Tropical Storm Watch is in effect for Dominica. Tropical storm conditions are expected to first reach the Lesser Antilles within the warning area by early Friday, Aug. 18.\n\nAt 11 a.m. EDT (1500 UTC), the disturbance was centered near 13.1 degrees north latitude and 54.1 degrees west longitude. The system was moving toward the west near 17 mph (28 kph) and this motion is expected to continue for the next couple of days. On the forecast track, the disturbance should move through the Windward Islands and into the eastern Caribbean Sea on Aug. 18. Maximum sustained winds are near 35 mph (55 kph) with higher gusts.\n\nThe NHC noted that the depression is expected to become a tropical storm before reaching the Windward Islands.\n\nThe depression is expected to bring heavy rainfall across portions of the Windward Islands from Martinique southward to Grenada with totals between 2 and 4 inches expected. These rains could cause life-threatening flash floods and mudslides.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "wgt": 100, "id": 605, "label": This will result in rapid weakening Thursday, and Gert is likely to transition to a non-tropical area of low pressure by Thursday night.\n\nThe good news is that this system is no direct threat to the United States, Bermuda or Atlantic Canada as it accelerates northeast, eventually getting caught up in the jet stream over the north Atlantic Ocean.\n\nWhile remaining several hundred miles off the East Coast, Hurricane Gert has still generated swells that will continue to affect areas from southeastern New England and coastal Maine to Atlantic Canada through Thursday. Rough surf may continue in eastern Canada into Thursday night as the hurricane steps on the gas with sights set on the open waters of the north Atlantic Ocean.\n\nDangerous rip currents will accompany the hurricane-generated swells, as well. A man drowned in heavy surf created by Hurricane Gert off Nobadeer Beach in Nantucket, Massachusetts, Wednesday morning.\n\n(LATEST NEWS: Hurricane Gert Whips Up Strong Waves Off East Coast; 1 Dead in Massachusetts)\n\nLate Sunday afternoon, Gert became the seventh named storm of the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season. Only three other years had seven or more tropical storms by Aug. 13: 1936, 1995 and 2005.\n\nElsewhere in the Atlantic, the National Hurricane Center has highlighted several areas of interest between Africa and the Lesser Antilles for possible development in the next five days.\n\n(MORE: Eastern Atlantic Monitored For Possible Tropical Development)\n\nCheck back with us at weather.com for the the warning area within 24-36 hours.\n\nAccording to the National Hurricane Centre (NHC) in Miami, environmental conditions appear generally conducive for development, and a tropical depression could form later on Thursday as the system moves westward at about 15 mph.\n\nIn the advisory issued on Thursday afternoon, the NHC said the disturbance was moving towards the west and this motion is The satellite imagery showed the circulation of the low pressure area was becoming better defined and that a cluster of strong convection has formed west of the center.\n\nNOAA manages the GOES series of satellites, and NASA uses the satellite data to create images and animations. The image was created by the NASA/NOAA GOES Project at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland.\n\nTropical Depression Nine (TD9) formed around 11 p.m. EDT on Aug. 17 about 365 miles east of the Barbados and 465 miles (750 km) east of St. Lucia.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center (NHC) issued a Tropical Storm Warning for Martinique, St. Lucia, Barbados, St. Vincent and the Grenadines. A Tropical Storm Watch is in effect for Dominica. Tropical storm conditions are expected to first reach the Lesser Antilles within the warning area by early Friday, Aug. 18.\n\nAt 11 a.m. EDT (1500 UTC), the disturbance was centered near 13.1 degrees north latitude and 54.1 degrees west longitude. The system was moving toward the west near 17 mph (28 kph) and this motion is expected to continue for the next couple of days. On the forecast track, the disturbance should move through the Windward Islands and into the eastern Caribbean Sea on Aug. 18. Maximum sustained winds are near 35 mph (55 kph) with higher gusts.\n\nThe NHC noted that the depression is expected to become a tropical storm before reaching the Windward Islands.\n\nThe depression is expected to bring heavy rainfall across portions of the Windward Islands from Martinique southward to Grenada with totals between 2 and 4 inches expected. PETERSBURG, FLA. (WTSP) - Just as Hurricane Gert begins to weaken as it moves into cooler waters of the north Atlantic, another storm is gathering strength east of the Caribbean.\n\nThe first in a series of tropical waves currently moving across the Atlantic has strengthened into Tropical Storm Harvey on Thursday afternoon. As of 5 p.m., Harvey is about 250 miles east of Barbados with maximum sustained winds of 40 miles per hour.\n\nTropical storm warnings are up for Martinique, St. Lucia, Barbados and St. Vincent and the Grenadines. A watch is in effect for Dominica.\n\nMore: Hurricane and tropical storm tracker\n\nHeavy rain and gusty winds are expected to spread into the eastern Caribbean Thursday night and Friday. Interests in these areas should continue to monitor the development of this system.\n\nTropical Storm Harvey is the eighth named storm of the Atlantic Hurricane Season. The storm will likely continue to develop as it moves west across the Caribbean into the middle of next week. As of Thursday, that forecast would take it toward the coast of Central America into the middle of next week.\n\n\u25baMake it easy to keep up-to-date with more stories like this. days.\n\nA tropical cyclone can take the form of a tropical depression, tropical storm, or hurricane.\n\nAnother system, a tropical wave, being watched by forecasters has yet to move off Africa, but The National Hurricane Center expects Harvey to enter the eastern Caribbean Sea by Friday afternoon.\n\nHarvey is not expected to affect Louisiana. Harvey is the ninth named storm of the 2017 Atlantic Ocean hurricane season.\n\nData gathered Thursday morning from an U.S. Air Force flight over the storm found Harvey had maximum winds around 40 miles per hour with stronger gusts.\n\nHarvey is currently moving west at 18 miles per hour.\n\nThe storm is expected to move through the Lesser Antilles overnight and enter the Caribbean on Friday. The current trajectory shows the storm moving into the western Caribbean over the weekend before hitting the Honduran coast Monday afternoon and then moving further inland toward Belize and Guatemala by Tuesday afternoon.\n\nA tropical storm warning is in effect for the islands of Martinique, St. Lucia, Barbados and St. Vincent and the Grenadines. The island of Dominica is under a tropical storm watch.\n\nCurrent forecasts do not show Harvey developing into a hurricane.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said it is watching various models to predict whether the storm will intensify or degenerate as it moves closer to Central America. open Atlantic, but still dangerous enough to generate life threatening coastal conditions, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) said Tuesday.\n\nGert, which become the second hurricane of the Atlantic season late Monday, was located at 8 PM PST some 675 kilometres (420 miles) west of Bermuda.\n\nThe Category One storm on the five-level Saffir-Simpson scale was moving towards the northeast into the Atlantic at about 17 kilometres (10 miles) per hour, with top sustained winds of 120 kilometres (75 miles) per hour.\n\n\"Swells generated by Gert will spread northward along the east coast of the United States from North Carolina northward to Long Island during the next couple of days,\" the Miami-based NHC said.\n\n\"These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip conditions.\"\n\nThe dangerous swells are also expected to affect Bermuda, the NHC said.\n\nForecasters say that Gert will gain strength and increase its forward speed in the next day.\n\nThe Atlantic {"sim": 0.6980392336845398, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9299570", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "phys.org", "title": "phys.org", "id": "2619"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "https://3c1703fe8d.site.internapcdn.net/newman/gfx/news/hires/2017/nasasgpmfoun.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 444, "textEnd": 459, "date": "2017-08-14", "freq": 3, "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3200, "textEnd": 3215, "date": "2017-08-19", "amb": false}], "url": "https://phys.org/news/2017-08-nasa-gpm-gert-hurricane.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:48:00", "title": "NASA's GPM found Gert strengthening into a hurricane", "uri": "709820437", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:48:00Z", "time": "14:48:00", "body": "NASA looked at the rainfall rates within Tropical Storm Gert as it continued to strengthen and found the most intense rainfall on the tropical cyclone's eastern side. Just over 12 hours later, Gert would strengthen into a hurricane. As Gert has strengthened, the storm began generating dangerous surf along the U.S. East coast.\n\nThe Global Precipitation Measurement mission or GPM core observatory satellite passed above tropical storm Gert on August 14, 2017 at 9:36 a.m. EDT (1336 UTC) when winds had reached about 57.5 mph (50 knots). Data collected by GPM's Microwave Imager (GMI) and Dual-Frequency Precipitation Radar (DPR) instruments were used to show the coverage and the intensity of rainfall around Tropical Storm Gert. The area covered by GPM's radar swath revealed that the most intense rainfall, measuring greater 3.5 inches (90 mm) per hour, was located in bands of rain on the eastern side of the storm.\n\nThat GPM pass was mentioned in a National Hurricane Center (NHC) Tropical Storm Gert Discussion that noted, \"A recent 1336 UTC (9:36 a.m. EDT) GMI overpass shows a large band of convection wrapping around the circulation ...\"\n\nAt NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, GPM's Radar (DPR Ku Band) data was used to create a 3-D cross-section view through Gert. This examination of the storm's 3-D precipitation structure showed that the tallest thunderstorms were located in an intense band of rain east of Gert's center. The tall thunderstorms in that band were shown by DPR to reach altitudes above 9.4 miles (15.2 km). GPM is a joint mission between NASA and the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, JAXA.\n\nOn Aug. 14 at 1:18 p.m. EDT (17:18 UTC) NASA-NOAA's Suomi NPP satellite captured a visible image of Tropical Storm Gert, located off the coast of the southeastern U.S. The image showed that the bulk of clouds were still on the eastern side of the storm, but powerful thunderstorms surrounded the low-level center of circulation. A thick band of thunderstorms also wrapped into the center from the south.\n\nOn August 14 at 11 p.m. EDT Gert become the second hurricane of the 2017 season.\n\nAt 5 a.m. EDT (0900 UTC), the center of Hurricane Gert was located near 31.8 degrees north latitude and 72.5 degrees west longitude. That's about 450 miles (725 km) west of Bermuda.\n\nGert was moving toward the north near 12 mph (19 km/h). A turn toward the northeast with an increase in forward speed is expected later today. Maximum sustained winds remained near 75 mph (120 kph) with higher gusts. Gert has the opportunity to gather some strength later today or Wednesday. The estimated minimum central pressure is 986 millibars.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center noted that as Gert has increased in strength, ocean swells generated by Gert will spread northward along the east coast of the United States from North Carolina northward to Long Island during the next couple of days. Swells are also expected to affect Bermuda during the next couple of days. These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions.\n\nGert is expected to travel toward the northeast over the open waters of the northern Atlantic Ocean and dissipate by Saturday August 19, 2017.", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "wgt": 100, "id": 605, "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric In addition, wind shear and drier air are expected to increase Thursday. This will result in rapid weakening Thursday into Friday, and Gert is likely to transition to a non-tropical area of low pressure by Friday.\n\nThe good news is that this system is no direct threat to the United States, Bermuda or Atlantic Canada as it accelerates northeast, eventually getting caught up in the jet stream over the north Atlantic Ocean.\n\nWhile remaining several hundred miles off the East Coast, Hurricane Gert has still generated swells that will continue to affect areas from southeastern New England and coastal Maine to Atlantic Canada through Thursday. Rough surf may continue in eastern Canada into Thursday night as the hurricane steps on the gas with sights set on the open waters of the north Atlantic Ocean.\n\nDangerous rip currents will accompany the hurricane-generated swells, as well. A man drowned in heavy surf created by Hurricane Gert off Nobadeer Beach in Nantucket, Massachusetts, Wednesday morning.\n\n(LATEST NEWS: Hurricane Gert Whips Up Strong Waves Off East Coast; 1 Dead in Massachusetts)\n\nLate Sunday afternoon, Gert became the seventh named storm of the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season. Only three other years had seven or more tropical storms by Aug. 13: 1936, 1995 and 2005.\n\nElsewhere in the Atlantic, the National Hurricane Center has highlighted several areas of interest between Africa and the Lesser Antilles for possible development in the next five days.\n\n(MORE: Eastern Atlantic Monitored For Possible Tropical Development)\n\nCheck back with us at weather.com for the {"sim": 0.6745098233222961, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370267", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9811106", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "caribbean360.com", "title": "Caribbean360", "id": "8086"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Barbados"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "http://d15h3ts9pue03r.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/tropical-storm-harvey.jpg?x23406", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 31, "textEnd": 46, "date": "2017-08-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.caribbean360.com/news/tropical-storm-harvey-track-towards-barbados", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:37:00", "title": "Tropical Storm Harvey on Track Towards Barbados | Caribbean360", "uri": "711215449", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:37:00Z", "time": "02:37:00", "body": "BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Thursday August 17, 2017 - Barbadians are bracing for Tropical Storm Harvey which forecasters say will pass very near or over the island tomorrow morning.\n\nWhat had been \"potential tropical cyclone number nine\" was upgraded to a storm this evening, and at 8 p.m. it was carrying maximum sustained winds near 40 miles per hour. At that time it was located about 205 miles east of Barbados and 310 miles east of St Lucia and moving towards the west at 18 miles per hour.\n\n\"This motion is expected to continue for the next couple of days. On the forecast track, Harvey should move through the Windward Islands and into the eastern Caribbean Sea on Friday,\" the National Hurricane Centre (NHC) in Miami said. \"Slow strengthening is possible during the next 48 hours.\"\n\nIn its bulletin issued around the same time, the Barbados Meteorological Service said the centre of Harvey is forecast to pass near or over the island around 8 a.m. tomorrow.\n\nBy late this evening and into the night, weather conditions had started to deteriorate, with pockets of moderate to heavy showers, thunderstorms and gusty winds starting to spread across Barbados.\n\nA tropical storm warning remains in effect for Barbados, St Lucia, Martinique, and St Vincent and the Grenadines, while the tropical storm watch issued for Dominica is still in place.\n\nTropical Storm Harvey is expected to produce rainfall totals of 2 to 4 inches across portions of the Windward Islands, from Martinique southward to Grenada. And forecasters say those rains could cause life-threatening flash floods and mudslides.\n\nIn anticipation of the storm, Government offices in Barbados closed from as early as 2:30 p.m., and the Barbados Chamber of Commerce and Industry recommended that private sector entities employ a staggered shutdown approach with offices closing at 2:30 p.m., retail stores at 3:30 p.m., and gas stations, supermarkets and other essentials by 4:30 p.m. Those recommendations followed detailed discussions with stakeholders in the National Emergency Operations Centre.\n\nIt was also announced that tomorrow's opening of the 13 Caribbean Festival of Arts (CARIFESTA VIII) would be postponed as a result of the storm. Minister of Culture Stephen Lashley, who made the disclosure, explained that the preparations for the impending weather system had significantly impacted the arrangements for the opening ceremony.\n\n\"The national response ahead of the system has forced the cancellation of the mandatory dress rehearsal which was scheduled to be held at Kensington Oval this evening...Immediate measures have also had to be taken to safeguard equipment at the venue,\" he explained, adding that due to the expected inclement weather, some flights had been cancelled and some of the delegations due to arrive in Barbados would therefore be delayed.\n\nA new date for the opening ceremony will be announced \"very shortly\", Lashley said.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.6745098233222961, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9226634", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "virginislandsdailynews.com", "title": "The Virgin Islands Daily News", "id": "5015"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/virginislandsdailynews.com/content/tncms/custom/image/95b63ab2-a8b4-11e5-8204-cfb6801a818b.jpg?_dc=1450792926", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.virginislandsdailynews.com/news/new-tropical-system-emerging-as-gert-intensifies-into-hurricane/article_294b4b39-9824-5b58-ad5f-2d9db2b091e9.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:26:00", "title": "New tropical system emerging as Gert intensifies into hurricane", "uri": "709634036", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T07:26:00Z", "time": "07:26:00", "body": "ST. THOMAS -- As one low-pressure area that swept through the area with little notice turns into a hurricane, another is building over the eastern Atlantic.\n\nInvest 91L on the National Hurricane Center's map of the South Atlantic was too early to call a hurricane or a tropical storm. The center instead labeled it a trough, an area of low pressure typically associated with the tropical wave systems that drive most tropical weather.\n\nInvest 91L follows on the heels of the storm that eventually became Hurricane Gert, which approached the area as a tropical wave before hooking northward.\n\nCarlos Anselmi, a forecaster for the National Weather Service, said it may be too soon to tell whether and how the system could impact territorial weather.\n\n\"What we are observing is that there exists a great uncertainty of what will be the final trajectory,\" he said.\n\nEven relatively slight shifts in the trough's path could make the difference between rain and shine in the territory, Anselmi said.\n\nOn Monday, the National Hurricane Center nudged the chance of cyclone activity -- from 20 percent over the next two days to 30 percent over the next two days. The longer-term forecast -- over the next five days -- gave the odds at 50 percent to 60 percent Monday evening.\n\n\"It's still a low chance, however, it's increasing,\" Anselmi said. \"At this time we have some uncertainty of what will be the impacts across the region because if the system develops, we could have tropical cyclone effects. If the system moves a couple of degrees, we can experience dry conditions or less active conditions.\"\n\nAmong the concerns is an elongated area of low pressure stretching from the weather system's current location in an oblong arc to the edge of the Lesser Antilles, which includes the Virgin Islands, Anselmi said. The total area where the storm can change stretches about 193,000 square miles Anselmi said. That is an area bigger than California, which is about 156,000 square miles.\n\n\"Anywhere in that area, the system can develop,\" he said. \"It all depends on where it's formed... that's why the uncertainty is so big. We need to keep watching and see what happens with this area.\"\n\nHurricane Gert\n\nOn Monday night, forecasters say Gert strengthened to become the second hurricane of the season in the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Gert was about 445 miles west of Bermuda late Monday and had maximum sustained winds of 75 mph. The storm was moving north at 8 mph.\n\nSwells generated by Gert will begin to affect portions of Bermuda and the U.S. East Coast -- from North Carolina to New York -- over the next couple of days.", {"sim": 0.6627451181411743, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9560449", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "eurekalert.org", "title": "EurekAlert!", "id": "5435"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "https://www.eurekalert.org/multimedia/pub/web/148193_web.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 280, "textEnd": 287, "date": "2017-08-15", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 965, "textEnd": 978, "date": "2017-08-16", "freq": 2, "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1397, "textEnd": 1404, "date": "2017-08-18", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1720, "textEnd": 1727, "date": "2017-08-17", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2017-08/nsfc-nil081617.php", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:34:00", "title": "NASA's infrared look at Hurricane Gert", "uri": "710532027", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T20:34:00Z", "time": "20:34:00", "body": "NASA's Aqua satellite provided an infrared look at the power within Atlantic Hurricane Gert and saw the hurricane had very cold cloud top temperatures.\n\nThe Atmospheric Infrared Sounder or AIRS instrument that flies aboard NASA's Aqua satellite analyzed Gert in infrared light on Aug. 15 at 2:17 p.m. EDT (1817 UTC). AIRS data showed Gert's cloud pattern had become better organized than it was earlier in the day, and Gert had a well-defined convective band of thunderstorms around the center.\n\nSome of the coldest cloud top temperatures exceeded minus 63 degrees Fahrenheit (minus 53 degrees Celsius). Storms with temperatures that cold are high in the troposphere and NASA research has shown they have the ability to generate heavy rain.\n\nEarlier in the day, Gert had exhibited hints of an eye in visible satellite imagery, but the AIRS infrared imagery didn't show an eye when NASA's Aqua satellite analyzed the storm.\n\nAt 11 a.m. EDT (15900 UTC) on Wednesday, Aug. 16, 2017, the center of Hurricane Gert was located near 36 degrees north latitude and 68.4 degrees west longitude. That's about 355 miles (575 km) northwest of Bermuda and 510 miles (820 km) south-southwest of Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada.\n\nGert was moving toward the northeast near 25 mph (41 kph). The National Hurricane Center (NHC) expects an even faster motion toward the northeast or east-northeast through early Friday, Aug. 18. The estimated minimum central pressure is 975 millibars. Maximum sustained winds increased to near 95 mph (150 kph) with higher gusts. Some additional strengthening is possible through Aug. 16 and then Gert is expected to weaken.\n\nGert is forecast to become an extratropical low pressure system by Thursday night, Aug. 17.\n\nAlthough Gert is not close to the coast, the hurricane is stirring up rough seas that are affecting U.S. East coastal areas. The National Hurricane Center said \"swells generated by Gert will spread northward along the east coast of the United States from Virginia northward to New England and Atlantic Canada during the next couple of days. Swells are also expected to continue to affect Bermuda through tonight. These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions.\"", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "wgt": 100, Hurricane force winds extended 25 miles from the compact storm while tropical winds reached 105 miles.\n\nOver the next couple of days, swells from the storm may produce dangerous rip currents and surf from North Carolina to Long Island as well as Bermuda, forecasters said. The storm could strengthen slightly over the next couple of days, but then begin to weaken as it heads into the North Atlantic.\n\nForecasters are also keeping watch on two other waves making their way west. About 1,000 miles east of the Antilles, a low pressure system packing showers and thunderstorms and heading west between 15 and 20 mph is expected to reach the Caribbean by Friday. The system could strengthen into a tropical depression -- forecasters give it a 40 percent chance -- as it crosses warm tropical waters, but will likely weaken once it arrives, they said.\n\nA second wave off the west coast of Africa and also moving between 15 and 20 mph could also gather strength as it moves west. But it's way too early to say where any of them will go.\n\nThe first wave is Invest 91L. It was located about 1,000 miles east of the Lesser Antilles early Wednesday and was moving to the west at 15-20 mph.\n\nThe hurricane center said it was still disorganized and will cross into the Caribbean on Friday.\n\nConditions are only marginal for it to intensify, the hurricane center said. It has a 40 percent chance of becoming a tropical depression over the next five days.\n\nThe second wave, Invest 92L, was about 600 miles west of the Cabo Verde Islands early Wednesday and is headed to the west-northwest at 15-20 mph.\n\nIt has a 40 percent chance of development over the next five days, but it could run in to a less favorable environment by the weekend.\n\nThe third wave was near the African coast early Wednesday. It has a 30 percent chance of development over five days and is expected to track to the west to west-northwest.\n\nIn addition to that, there's Gert, the strongest hurricane so far in 2017 in the Atlantic.\n\nAs of 4 a.m. CDT Wednesday, Hurricane Gert was located about 330 miles northwest of Bermuda and was moving northeast at 21 mph.\n\nGert's winds increased to 90 mph, and the hurricane center said it could get stronger today before beginning a weakening trend.\n\nGert was no direct threat to land. However, waves generated by Gert will impact shores from Virginia to New England for the next few days.\n\nThose rough seas could also cause rip currents, the hurricane center said.", "date": On the forecast track, Gert is expected to pass about midway between the United States east coast and Bermuda on Tuesday,\" the NHC said in its 5 a.m. advisory.\n\n\"Some strengthening is forecast during the next 48 hours, and Gert could become a hurricane by Wednesday.\"\n\nCurrently, however, there are no hazards affecting land.\n\nElsewhere in the Atlantic, the NHC highlighted a new area of interest off the coast of Africa for a medium chance of development in the next five days.\n\nLast week, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) updated its hurricane season outlook, saying this season has the potential to be extremely active, and could be the most active since 2010.\n\nForecasters now say there is a 60 per cent chance of an above-normal season (compared to the May prediction of 45 per cent chance), with 14-19 named storms (increased from the May predicted range of 11-17) and 2-5 major hurricanes (increased from the May predicted range of 2-4). {"sim": 0.6392157077789307, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9131812", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "title": "CTV News", "id": "30"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Canada"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Halifax"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/polopoly_fs/1.2393973.1432754379!/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/landscape_620/image.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1487, "textEnd": 1493, "date": "-06-01", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/tropical-storm-gert-expected-to-have-little-impact-on-atlantic-canada-1.3545092", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:36:00", "title": "Tropical storm Gert expected to have little impact on Atlantic Canada", "uri": "709361682", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:36:00Z", "time": "17:36:00", "body": "HALIFAX -- A tropical storm moving up the United States east coast is expected to produce storm-force winds over the southern Grand Banks later this week, but will otherwise have little impact on Atlantic Canada.\n\nEnvironment Canada meteorologist Darin Borgel said tropical storm Gert is expected to become a hurricane Tuesday.\n\n\"But it is not expected to have any direct impact on the Canadian land territory. At this time it's expected to turn off to the northeast and track across the southern Grand Banks sometime on Thursday morning,\" Borgel said Monday.\n\nHe said coastal parts of Atlantic Canada may see slightly higher than normal waves as the storm passes, but otherwise won't see any impact from the storm.\n\nBorgel said marine interests will need to keep an eye on the forecast.\n\n\"I expect anyone travelling those waters are already pretty aware of what's going on. We are mentioning some gale storm force winds in our long range extended marine forecast,\" he said.\n\nHe said Gert will remain 500 to 600 kilometres off the coast.\n\nThe U.S. National Hurricane Center said Gert was centred about 735 kilometres west-southwest of Bermuda Monday morning and had maximum sustained winds of 95 km/h. It was moving toward the north-northwest at 16 km/h.\n\nA gradual turn toward the northeast with an increase in forward speed was forecast for the next 48 hours and Gert is expected to become a hurricane by Tuesday night.\n\nGert is the ninth storm since the tropical storm season started June 1, but the first to have any impact on Atlantic Canada.\n\nBorgel says the peak of the season is usually in August and September when the waters of the North Atlantic are at their warmest.\n\nThose warm water temperatures and a weak or non-existent El Nino are expected to contribute to an above-normal hurricane season this year.\n\nThe U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted 11 to 17 named storms this year, with five to nine expected to become hurricanes and two to four expected to become major in force.\n\nAn average of 35 to 40 per cent of storms that form in the Atlantic Basin actually make it into the Canadian Hurricane Centre's response zone, meaning anywhere from four to six storms could affect Canada this year.\n\nA strong El Nino -- the warming of waters in the Pacific Ocean -- can suppress hurricanes in the Atlantic.\n\nHurricane seasons tend to be quieter in years with a strong El Nino and more active in years with La Nina conditions -- like in 2016.\n\nLast year there were 15 named storms, seven of which reached hurricane status, with four of those reaching major hurricane status. A typical year has 12 storms, six hurricanes and three major hurricanes.", "date": "2017-08-14", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences", "wgt": 100, "id": 89, "label": Swells are also expected to affect Bermuda during the next couple of days. These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions,' the NHC added. {"sim": 0.6274510025978088, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9100598", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "birminghammail.co.uk", "title": "birminghammail", "id": "1004"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "http://i3.birminghammail.co.uk/news/midlands-news/article13475281.ece/ALTERNATES/s1200/gertPNG.png", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/midlands-news/tropical-storm-gert-could-blow-13475286", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:42:00", "title": "Tropical Storm Gert could blow better weather off course", "uri": "709281540", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T11:33:00Z", "time": "11:33:00", "body": "Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nForecasters are predicting that temperatures will soar to the mid 20s C by the weekend if a ridge of high pressure takes charge of the UK's weather.\n\nBut a Tropical Storm called Gert brewing in the Atlantic may still dash hopes of a rare glimpse of summer for sun-starved Brits. Repeated low pressure systems from the north Atlantic have dominated for much of July and August, but there is a glimmer of hope that a high could take control to temporarily banish blustery showers from Britain.\n\nThe high is expected to build by the weekend and potentially this could lure sunshine and warmer weather to most of the British Isles.\n\nForecaster Hannah Findley, of The Weather Channel , said that confidence in forecasts for the upcoming week was low because of the possible impact of Tropical Storm Gert.\n\nAn area of low pressure will absorb the worst of the storm as it moves towards the UK - hopefully leaving the way clear for higher pressure to take charge.\n\nAfter this low passes, there will be an area of high pressure over the UK from the middle of next week. Differing forecast models dispute the effect it will have on the country's weather.\n\nSome predictions indicate the high will be filled with warm tropical air, while other options go for cooler conditions with temperatures and rainfall around normal for the time of year, although this could still change.\n\nTemperatures could rise to the low 20s C on Saturday and climb towards 25C (77F) in the south-east on Sunday and Monday, according to some forecasters.\n\nThe Met Office agreed there was a chance that dry and brighter spells would develop - although its long-range forecast indicated that this was more likely in the south of the country.\n\nIt stated: \"For a time during the week there is a small chance of more settled weather becoming established across the UK with the greatest chance of some warmer spells developing in the south.\"\n\n--------------------------------------------------\n\nTROPICAL STORM GERT: COULD IT BLOW SUNSHINE HOPES AWAY?\n\nTropical Storm Gert is currently languishing in the Atlantic but it is unlikely to make landfall. It has been formed from a series of depressions developing into a tropical storm, but it will remain well off the East Coast of America before heading towards Europe.\n\nHowever it is likely to fizzle out before arriving close to the UK.\n\nIn the next few days, Gert is set to curl north along the west side of the Bermuda in a high-pressure system, then accelerate northeast before it gets caught up in the jet stream over the north Atlantic.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now\n\nThe US National Hurricane Centre stated that Gert had maximum sustained winds of 40 mph and was moving from the area around Bermuda towards the Florida coast at 10 mph.\n\nIt is expected to strengthen during the next few days and move further east into the Atlantic after Wednesday. Tropical cyclones normally develop from depressions close to the Equator.\n\nThese merge into storms and usually drift into areas dominated by westerly winds which blows the system to the east. As they pick up speed, storms can reach 30mph and an average tropical cyclone can travel about 300 to 400 miles a day, or about 3,000 miles before it dies out.\n\nThe UK is sometimes affected by deep depressions that are the remnants of tropical cyclones which produce winds of a strength equivalent to a tropical cyclone", "date": "2017-08-14", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences", {"sim": 0.6235294342041016, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9127427", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "coventrytelegraph.net", "title": "coventrytelegraph", "id": "2070"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "http://i4.coventrytelegraph.net/incoming/article13221647.ece/ALTERNATES/s1200/JS99511395.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.coventrytelegraph.net/news/uk-world-news/storm-gert-uk-weather-warning-13475415", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:11:00", "title": "Storm Gert UK weather warning as warm weather blown off course", "uri": "709350125", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T12:42:00Z", "time": "12:42:00", "body": "Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nTemperatures in the UK could soar into the mid-20s this weekend.\n\nThat's the message from meteorologists, who expect a ridge of high pressure to transform the forecast in Britain.\n\nUnfortunately, some are warning about a Tropical Storm named Gert which is currently brewing in the Atlantic.\n\nIt is feared the storm could dash hopes UK residents have of some August sunshine.\n\nAccording to the Birmingham Mail, repeated low pressure systems from the north Atlantic have dominated for much of July and August.\n\nBut there is a glimmer of hope that a high could take control to temporarily banish blustery showers from Britain.\n\nThe high is expected to build by the weekend and potentially this could lure sunshine and warmer weather to most of the British Isles.\n\nForecaster Hannah Findley, of The Weather Channel, said that confidence in forecasts for the upcoming week was low because of the possible impact of Tropical Storm Gert.\n\nAn area of low pressure will absorb the worst of the storm as it moves towards the UK - hopefully leaving the way clear for higher pressure to take charge.\n\nAfter this low passes, there will be an area of high pressure over the UK from the middle of next week. Differing forecast models dispute the effect it will have on the country's weather.\n\nSome predictions indicate the high will be filled with warm tropical air, while other options go for cooler conditions with temperatures and rainfall around normal for the time of year, although this could still change.\n\nTemperatures could rise to the low 20s Celsius on Saturday and climb towards 25C (77F) in the south-east on Sunday and Monday, according to some forecasters.\n\nThe Met Office agreed there was a chance that dry and brighter spells would develop - although its long-range forecast indicated that this was more likely in the south of the country.\n\nIt stated: \"For a time during the week there is a small chance of more settled weather becoming established across the UK with the greatest chance of some warmer spells developing in the south.\"\n\n--------------------------------------------------\n\nTROPICAL STORM GERT: COULD IT BLOW SUNSHINE HOPES AWAY?\n\nTropical Storm Gert is currently languishing in the Atlantic but it is unlikely to make landfall. It has been formed from a series of depressions developing into a tropical storm, but it will remain well off the East Coast of America before heading towards Europe.\n\nHowever it is likely to fizzle out before arriving close to the UK.\n\nIn the next few days, Gert is set to curl north along the west side of the Bermuda in a high-pressure system, then accelerate northeast before it gets caught up in the jet stream over the north Atlantic.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now\n\nThe US National Hurricane Centre stated that Gert had maximum sustained winds of 40 mph and was moving from the area around Bermuda towards the Florida coast at 10 mph.\n\nIt is expected to strengthen during the next few days and move further east into the Atlantic after Wednesday. Tropical cyclones normally develop from depressions close to the Equator.\n\nThese merge into storms and usually drift into areas dominated by westerly winds which blows the system to the east. As they pick up speed, storms can reach 30mph and an average tropical cyclone can travel about 300 to 400 miles a day, or about 3,000 miles before it dies out.\n\nThe UK is sometimes affected by deep depressions that are the remnants of tropical cyclones which produce winds of a strength equivalent to a tropical cyclone.\n\nRead More Monday's must-read stories\n\nDownload our all-new mobile app to get the latest news, sport and what's on.\n\nOne quick sync and you can read our content on the move without being online.\n\nGet regular news alerts straight to your mobile and keep up with the latest traffic and travel or breaking events as they happen via our daily live blogs.\n\nIt's completely customisable to your own specific interests.\n\nDownload it today by clicking here for iPhone and here for Android\n\nLooking for an older story? By 5 p.m. the depression strengthened into a tropical storm and was named Gert.\n\nAt 1 p.m. EDT (1700 UTC) on Sunday, August 13, NOAA's GOES-East satellite captured a visible image of Tropical Depression 8 that showed the storm had become better organized. Bands of thunderstorms were spiraling into the center of circulation from the east and the southern quadrants of the storm. NOAA manages the GOES series of satellites. NASA/NOAA's GOES Project at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland uses the satellite data to create imagery.\n\nBy 1:36 p.m. EDT (1736 UTC) on August 13, The Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) instrument aboard NASA-NOAA's Suomi NPP satellite provided a visible look at Gert. Bands of thunderstorms wrapped around the storm from southeast to northeast.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center (NHC) noted that imagery showed that between the morning and 5 p.m. EDT \"the banding features have become better established during the last several hours, and the system has become less vertically tilted.\"\n\nOn August 14 at 5 a.m. EDT (0900 UTC) the center of Tropical Storm Gert was located near 29.7 degrees north latitude and 72.2 degrees west longitude. That's about 475 miles (760 km) west-southwest of Bermuda. The estimated minimum central pressure is 1009 millibars. Maximum sustained winds are near 45 mph (75 kph) with higher gusts.\n\nGert was moving toward the north-northwest near 9 mph (15 kph) and the NHC forecasts a turn toward the north then to north-northeast. On the forecast track, Gert is expected to pass about midway between the United States east coast and Bermuda on Tuesday\n\nThe NHC said that some strengthening is forecast during the next 48 hours, And let's not forget Hurricane Bertha a year before that.\n\nGert will be here over Saturday and Sunday (August 19-20) so here's everything you need to know about the next significant UK weather event on the way.\n\nWhat is Hurricane Gert?\n\nMet Office meteorologist Clare Nasir said: \"This time of year, mid summer to autumn time, occasionally we see the odd hurricane modified by the cool waters of the north Atlantic that slowly move up.\"\n\nShe added the hurricane will become a \"typical depression\" by the time the cool water has moved across to western Europe.\n\nHurricane Gert is currently a category one storm and is the north Atlantic's second hurricane this year.\n\nWhere is Gert right now?\n\nAt the moment, Gert is travelling eastwards, parallel to the USA coast.\n\nHowever, by Wednesday (August 16) into Thursday (August 17), she will be touring the east side of Canada, where she is upgraded to an \"ex hurricane\".\n\nMs Nasir continued: \"By the time it gets to the mid-Atlantic, it becomes a typical mid-Atlantic depression, so a deep area of low pressure.\"\n\nWhen will Gert arrive in the UK?\n\nGert will cross the waters to the UK coast on Friday (August 18) and will arrive fully by \"the latter part of the weekend and into next week\".\n\nIn short, this means a lot of wet and windy weather is on the way.\n\n\"Currently we are expecting some wet and windy weather, some heavy rain from time to time, particularly in the northern half of the UK,\" it is added.\n\nWhile there is a small chance of some \"fine and warm weather\", The system was moving at about 13 mph.\n\nThe depression would earn the name Gert when winds increase to 39 mph.\n\nA turn toward the north is forecast to occur Sunday night, and to the north-northeast on Monday.\n\nForecasters are also watching a tropical wave that has moved off the west coast of Africa. That system is forecast to move westward over the next couple of days and merge with a broad area of low pressure located southwest of the Cabo Verde Islands.\n\nEnvironmental conditions are expected to be ripe for gradual strengthening. Storm formation chance through 48 hours are near zero percent, and 20 percent over five days.\n\nmwclary@sunsentinel.com", "date": "2017-08-13", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.6196078658103943, "details": {"gpCnt": 3, "liCnt": 3}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9111962", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "nj.com", "title": "NJ.com (New Jersey)", "id": "144"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "http://image.nj.com/home/njo-media/width620/img/new-jersey-weather/photo/tropical-storm-gert-rough-seasjpeg-ac5660224791a767.jpeg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2429, "textEnd": 2435, "date": "-06-01", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2453, "textEnd": 2460, "date": "-11-30", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.nj.com/weather/index.ssf/2017/08/tropical_storm_gert_could_boost_waves_and_rip_curr.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:43:00", "title": "Tropical Storm Gert could generate rip currents along N.J. shore ", "uri": "709309912", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:37:00Z", "time": "15:37:00", "body": "Although Tropical Storm Gert is churning hundreds of miles away from the eastern seaboard and poses no direct threat to land, it is expected to generate big waves and potentially dangerous rip currents along the Jersey Shore and other beaches on the Atlantic Ocean, forecasters said.\n\nGert, which was named on Sunday when a tropical depression strengthened into a tropical storm north of the Bahamas, has been packing sustained winds of 60 mph. As of late Monday morning, the storm's center was about 460 miles southwest of Bermuda and moving north at a pace of 8 mph, the National Hurricane Center reported.\n\nForecasters expect Gert to remain at least 250 miles away from the Atlantic coast, but that's still close enough to produce swelling that will boost wave heights and likely increase the risk of dangerous rip currents along the Jersey Shore, New York City and Long Island beaches, Delaware and the Carolinas, according to AccuWeather and the National Weather Service.\n\nAtlantic hurricane season 'extremely active'\n\nBeaches in New Jersey and Delaware have a low risk of dangerous rip currents Monday morning and afternoon, but the risk is expected to rise to \"at least a moderate level\" Monday night through Tuesday night, said Lance Franck, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service's regional office in Mount Holly.\n\nA similar situation is anticipated in New York City and Long Island, although it's not yet part of the official weather service forecast, said John Murray, a meteorologist at the weather service's office in Upton, N.Y.\n\n\"By mid-week, we'll have some 5-foot waves along the ocean. With the increasing wave heights, we'll have more of an on-shore flow, so we are going to have a little higher risk of rip currents,\" Murray said. \"That's typically what we see when we have a tropical cyclone out in the Atlantic.\"\n\nAs Gert passes between Bermuda and the outer banks of North Carolina on Tuesday, the roughest surf conditions are anticipated from South Carolina up to the Delmarva Peninsula, according to AccuWeather forecasters.\n\nEven though Gert will remain far offshore,the southeastern U.S. could face heavy rain and localized flash flooding because of a non-tropical system, AccuWeather said, noting that the Northeast region \"will gradually turn stormier and steamy as the weak progresses.\"\n\nGert is the seventh named storm of the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season, which officially kicked off on June 1 and runs through Nov. 30. Last week, the national Climate Prediction Center revised its original projections on how many named storms are likely to develop, saying this hurricane season is becoming \"extremely active.\"", sustained winds are expected to increase to near 45 mph (72km/h) with higher gusts.\n\nMinimum central pressure is currently 1004 millibars.\n\nModerate to heavy showers, periods of rain, thunderstorms and gusty winds will continue to affect the island throughout this morning.\n\nFurther rainfall accumulations of 2 to 3 inches (50 to 75 millimetres) are still possible.\n\nIn addition, seas will continue to be rough in open waters with swells of up to 3 meters (10ft).\n\nResidents and motorist in flood prone areas, areas prone to land-slippage, near rivers and streams should be on the alert and take all necessary precautions.\n\nA small craft warning is in effect for rough seas and high winds.\n\nThe St. Vincent and the Grenadines Meteorological Office will continue to monitor The Windward Islands covering Martinique, the Grenadines, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and Barbados were under a tropical storm warning.\n\nThe storm, moving west at 18 mph, is expected to cross into the Caribbean on Friday. It does not pose a threat to Florida, but forecasters warned the storm could dump between two and four inches of rain over the Windward Islands, triggering dangerous floods and mudslides.\n\nIt's expected to steadily strengthen over the next week, but then weaken once it encounters higher wind shear in the central Caribbean, forecasters said. Models show the storm tracking to the northwest, and reaching the eastern Caribbean over the next day or so.\n\nMeanwhile, a second wave in the central Atlantic more likely to threaten Florida also became better formed Thursday. In their 2 p.m. advisory, forecasters said over the next day or so, it's possible this system could also become a cyclone and upped the odds of it forming to 60 percent over the next 48 hours.\n\nThe system was located about 1,200 miles east of the Leeward Islands, which it will likely reach by the weekend. As it nears the islands, conditions become less favorable so it's possible it could weaken again. The system was headed west, northwest at about 20 mph.\n\nForecasters are also watching a third wave rolling off Africa's west coast, which they say could also become a cyclone as it heads west about 15 mph.\n\nHaving three storms on their radar is not unusual for forecasters at this time of year when the Atlantic basin typically produces its highest number of hurricanes. Harvey is a small storm, he said.\n\nHarvey's center is expected to pass about 300 miles south of the territory tonight and early Saturday, Figueroa said, adding that local marine conditions could start deteriorating late today.\n\nAs of press time this morning, Harvey's tropical storm force winds extended out up to 60 miles north of the center, according to the National Hurricane Center. southern Caribbean toward Central America.\n\nFigueroa said he is keeping a close eye on another tropical disturbance that is behind Harvey.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Thursday that an area of low pressure about 1,000 miles east of the Leeward Islands has a 70 percent chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within the next 48 hours.\n\nOnly a slight increase in organization of the shower and thunderstorms in that area could lead to the formation of a tropical depression, according to the Hurricane Center.\n\nThat low is expected to move west-northwestward at about 20 mph for the next few days, and the Hurricane Center advised residents in the northern Leeward Islands to monitor it.\n\nRight now, computer models show it passing to the north of the territory on Monday or week, but otherwise will not impact Atlantic Canada.\n\nEnvironment Canada meteorologist Darin Borgel says tropical storm Gert is expected to become a hurricane Tuesday, but steer well clear of the region when it passes on Thursday.\n\nBorgel says coastal parts of Newfoundland may see slightly higher than normal waves as the storm passes, but otherwise won't see any impact from the storm.\n\nHe says Gert will remain 500 to 600 kilometres off the coast.\n\nGert is the ninth storm since the tropical storm season started June 1, but the first to have any impact on Atlantic Canada.\n\nBorgel The system is moving toward the west near 17 mph (28 km/h) and this motion is expected to continue for the next couple of days. The disturbance should move through the Windward Islands, with the center crossing our islands SVG and into the eastern Caribbean Sea on Friday. This afternoon, an Air Force Reserve reconnaissance aircraft is scheduled to investigate the approaching area (disturbance). At 11:00 a.m, the center is near 13.1N 54.1W or 470 miles (760 km) east of SVG. Maximum sustained winds are near 35 mph (55 km/h) with higher gusts. Minimum central pressure of 1008mb.....29.77 inches\n\nSqually conditions with moderate to heavy showers, periods of rain and thunderstorm activity with gusty winds could move across St. Vincent and the Grenadines this evening into Friday. Favourable upper level pattern across the islands could result in enhancement of this system which has a high (80-90%) chance of becoming a tropical storm as it crosses our area. Tropical storm conditions are possible overnight into early Friday, making outside preparations difficult or dangerous. Sustained winds of 34 to 63 knots (39 to 73 mph/ 63 to 118 km/h) are possible across our area within the next 6 to 9 hours.\n\nRainfall accumulations of 4 - 5 inches (100 - 125mm) can be expected, with higher amounts over mountainous terrain. These rains could cause life-threatening flash floods and mudslides.\n\nMarine conditions are expected to become moderate to rough on Friday with sea swells increasing to 2.0 m - 2.5 m (7 - 8 feet).\n\nInstability is expected to linger Saturday into Sunday with some showers as the second area of low pressure with a medium 50-60% chance for development, passes just north of the Lesser Antilles on a west-northwest track away from St. Vincent and the Grenadines.\n\nTropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are possible across St. Vincent and the Grenadines within 24-36 hours.\n\nPrepared by J. bubbling up in the Atlantic, is putting predictions of a balmy weekend for the UK in serious doubt .\n\nSome experts had predicted days of warm sunshine for much of the UK with the worst of Gert's turbulent conditions being swallowed up by low pressure on its way across the ocean.\n\nBut other forecasts indicated remnants of the storm could put paid to any summer-like weather for Britain.\n\nLatest predictions in the US revealed Gert had strengthened to become the second hurricane of the Atlantic season.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center in Miami said Gert was about 445 miles west of Bermuda late on Monday and had sustained winds of 75 mph as it moved north.\n\nIt is expected to strengthen in the next 48 hours as it turns north-east towards the UK and accelerates on pressure away allowing cooler, wet and blustery conditions to take charge instead.\n\nForecasters from The Weather Channel predicted a new low pressure system would approach the British Isles on churning its way east across the Atlantic and is likely to strengthen as it turns towards the north-east and picks up speed.\n\nThe giant storm's remnants are expected to hit Britain, adding more woes to a summer that has already been one of the coldest in 35 years.\n\nGert could nudge a ridge of high pressure out of the way, leading to cooler, wet and blustery conditions for parts of the UK.\n\nSome experts had predicted days of warm sunshine for much of the UK with the worst of Gert's turbulent conditions being swallowed up by low pressure on its way across the ocean.\n\nHowever, {"sim": 0.5882353186607361, "details": {"liCnt": 3}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9115722", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "title": "Washington Post", "id": "104"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "https://img.washingtonpost.com/pbox.php?url=http://img.washingtonpost.com/blogs/capital-weather-gang/files/2017/08/rbtop0.gif&w=1484&op=resize&opt=1&filter=antialias&t=20170517", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 710, "textEnd": 718, "date": "2017-09-13", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 754, "textEnd": 761, "date": "2017-08-29", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2017/08/14/tropical-storm-gert-may-become-this-seasons-second-atlantic-hurricane/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:04:00", "title": "Tropical Storm Gert may become this season's second Atlantic hurricane", "uri": "709319864", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T16:04:00Z", "time": "16:04:00", "body": "Tropical Storm Gert is expected to strengthen over the next couple of days, but it's no threat to land. (NOAA)\n\nTropical Storm Gert, which formed over the weekend, is halfway between Florida and Bermuda, and headed toward open ocean. However, it is also strengthening and could become the season's second hurricane by mid-week. It is not a threat to land.\n\nGert's winds are estimated at 45 mph, but intensification is expected as it recurves and interacts with a mid-latitude trough. After a brief time window of gaining energy from the trough, Gert will transition to an extratropical cyclone (non-tropical) by the end of the week.\n\nClimatologically (over the past 50 years), the seventh named storm forms on Sept. 13, and the second hurricane forms on Aug. 29, so by both of those metrics the season is well ahead of par. Even if Gert does not quite reach hurricane status, the odds are good that some other storm will by the end of the month.\n\nBehind Tropical Storm Gert, another area of thunderstorms is being monitored by the National Hurricane Center. Although it is a bit messy at the moment, environmental conditions appear to be marginally favorable for development later this week, so it is certainly a feature of interest.\n\n(EUMETSAT)\n\nMost reliable global models are predicting some degree of development, but given the amount of dry mid-level air ahead of it, any significant intensification is unlikely through the weekend. In terms of tracks, some models take it over the Greater Antilles while others recurve it northward before reaching the Lesser Antilles. In this plot, the U.S.' global model, GFS, is shown -- the single \"deterministic\" run in the thick black line, and the \"ensemble\" runs in the colored lines. Only 1 of the 20 ensemble members indicates a storm of hurricane intensity, and that's six days out.\n\nThis is nothing to be concerned about now, just something to keep an eye on. If it does form and reach tropical storm status, the next name on the list is Harvey. This time of year, a new easterly wave exits the African continent every 4-6 days, and these easterly waves are the primary hurricane formation mechanism during the heart of the season.", "date": And let's not forget Hurricane Bertha a year before that.\n\nRead More Latest Weather Headlines\n\nGert will be here over Saturday and Sunday (August 19-20) so here's everything you need to know about the next significant UK weather event on the way.\n\nWhat is Hurricane Gert?\n\nMet Office meteorologist Clare Nasir said: \"This time of year, mid summer to autumn time, occasionally we see the odd hurricane modified by the cool waters of the north Atlantic that slowly move up.\"\n\nShe added the hurricane will become a \"typical depression\" by the time the cool water has moved across to western Europe.\n\nHurricane Gert is currently a category one storm and is the north Atlantic's second hurricane this year.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now Where is Gert right now?\n\nAt the moment, Gert is travelling eastwards, parallel to the USA coast.\n\nHowever, by Wednesday (August 16) into Thursday (August 17), she will be touring the east side of Canada, where she is upgraded to an \"ex hurricane\".\n\nMs Nasir continued: \"By the time it gets to the mid-Atlantic, it becomes a typical mid-Atlantic depression, so a deep area of low pressure.\"\n\nWhen will Gert arrive in the UK?\n\nGert will cross the waters to the UK coast on Friday (August 18) and will arrive fully by \"the latter part of the weekend and into next week\".\n\nIn short, this means a lot of wet and windy weather is on the way.\n\n\"Currently we are expecting some wet and windy weather, some heavy rain from time to time, particularly in the northern half of the UK,\" it is added.\n\nWhile there is a small chance of some \"fine and warm weather\", unsurprisingly, it is more likely to be \"heavy rain and perhaps strong winds\".\n\nKeep up And let's not forget Hurricane Bertha a year before that.\n\nRead More Latest weather headlines\n\nGert will be here over Saturday and Sunday (August 19 to August 20) so here's everything you need to know about the next significant UK weather event on the way.\n\nWhat is Hurricane Gert?\n\nMet Office meteorologist Clare Nasir said: \"This time of year, mid summer to autumn time, occasionally we see the odd hurricane modified by the cool waters of the north Atlantic that slowly move up.\"\n\nShe added the hurricane will become a \"typical depression\" by the time the cool water has moved across to western Europe.\n\nHurricane Gert is currently a category one storm and is the north Atlantic's second hurricane this year.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now Where is Gert right now?\n\nAt the moment, Gert is travelling eastwards, parallel to the USA coast.\n\nHowever, by Wednesday (August 16) into Thursday (August 17), she will be touring the east side of Canada, where she is upgraded to an \"ex hurricane\".\n\nMs Nasir continued: \"By the time it gets to the mid-Atlantic, it becomes a typical mid-Atlantic depression, so a deep area of low pressure.\"\n\nWhen will Gert arrive in the UK?\n\nGert will cross the waters to the UK coast on Friday (August 18) and will arrive fully by \"the latter part of the weekend and into next week\".\n\nIn short, this means a lot of wet and windy weather is on the way.\n\n\"Currently we are expecting some wet and windy weather, some heavy rain from time to time, particularly in the northern half of the UK,\" it is added.\n\nWhile there is a small chance of some \"fine and warm weather\", unsurprisingly, it is more likely to be \"heavy rain and perhaps strong
