On the forecast track, the disturbance should move through the Windward Islands and into the eastern Caribbean Sea on Friday.\n\nMaximum sustained winds are near 35 mph (55 km/h) with higher gusts. The disturbance is expected to become a tropical cyclone later today or tonight and it could become a tropical storm before reaching the Windward Islands.\n\nA Tropical Storm Watch means that tropical storm conditions are possible within the watch area, in this case within 24-36 hours.\n\nExpected rainfall amount for Dominica is between 2 to 3 inches (50 to 75mm) with higher amounts in elevated areas.\n\n\u00b7 Mariners and other users of the sea should remain extremely cautious and do not venture far from port.\n\n\u00b7 Persons in areas prone to flooding, landslides and falling rocks are advised to be extremely vigilant and to exercise caution as flash flooding and winds gusting to tropical storm force are possible tonight into Friday.\n\n\u00b7 Residents in vulnerable areas should plan ahead and take all precautionary measures throughout tonight and into Friday. Be on the lookout for fast rising water. That name is Gert. Late Sunday afternoon officials with the National Hurricane Center verified that the system had met the criteria to reach tropical storm status. That's the bad news. The good news is that Gert appears to be an ocean storm. It should not affect any land mass at all.\n\nThe forecast track for Gert suggests that the center of circulation will pass well to the east of the United States and well to the west of the island nation of Bermuda. The storm is expected to reach hurricane status during the day on Wednesday.\n\nFurther to the east off of the coast of Africa forecasters are monitoring another tropical wave that is showing signs of strengthening. This wave is at least a week a way from being anywhere close to the outer islands of the Caribbean. low pressure on its way across the ocean.\n\nHowever, other forecasts indicated remnants of the storm could put paid to any summer-like weather for Britain.\n\nLatest predictions in the US revealed Gert had strengthened to become the second hurricane of the Atlantic season.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center in Miami said Gert was about 445 miles west of Bermuda late on Monday and had sustained winds of 75 mph as it moved north.\n\nIt is expected to strengthen in the next 48 hours as it turns north-east towards the UK and accelerates on Tuesday night.\n\nRemnants of Gert are likely to affect Britain for several days with continued unsettled, changeable weather forecast for the next week.\n\nIt is set to blow previously-predicted high pressure away allowing cooler, wet and blustery conditions to take charge instead.\n\nForecasters from The Weather Channel predicted a new low pressure system would approach the British Isles on Wednesday bringing widespread showers, or longer "1280"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "http://cdn.images.dailystar.co.uk/dynamic/1/photos/687000/936x622/1044687.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/latest-news/637816/uk-weather-forecast-storm-gert-hurricane", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:25:00", "title": "Storm Gert becomes 'life-threatening' HURRICANE as UK braced for showers and thunder", "uri": "710250964", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T10:25:00Z", "time": "10:25:00", "body": "GETTY\n\nMORE MISERY: The tail end of Storm Gert could bring torrid weather to Britain\n\nSatellite images from NASA showed the massive storm strengthening off the east coast of the US.\n\nThe US-based National Hurricane Center (NHC) upgraded Storm Gert to a hurricane yesterday as it tracked past the Caribbean.\n\nThe giant depression is now bending north-east across the Atlantic Ocean, with its remnants expected to affect Britain for several days into the weekend.\n\nForecasters believe Storm Gert could dislodge high pressure over the UK, paving the way for cooler temperatures, downpours and high winds.\n\nAlthough Storm Gert is not expected to make landfall in the US, the NHC is warning of \"life-threatening surf and rip currents\" along coastal areas.\n\nAPOCALYPTIC storms batter the UK The UK was illuminated by one of the greatest and most terrifying lightning storms in recent times, last night 1 / 26 Sam Whitfied / SWNS.com Views accros Dartmoor\n\nNASA\n\nCOLOSSAL: A NASA satellite image shows the hurricane in the Atlantic\n\nThe NHC said: \"Swells generated by Gert will spread northward along the east coast of the United States from North Carolina northward to Long Island during the next couple of days.\n\n\"Swells are also expected to affect Bermuda during the next couple of days.\n\n\"These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions.\"\n\nBy the weekend, forecasters fear the tail of Storm Gert may bring torrential rain, thunder and gale force winds to the UK.\n\nIn the meantime low pressure is already sweeping in from the Atlantic, meaning a weather \"horrow show\" in the coming days.\n\nNHC\n\nSTRENGTHENING: Storm Gert is building up energy off the east coast of the US\n\n\"These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions.\"\n\nThe NHC\n\nThe Met Office is forecasting more showers, grey skies and blustery conditions throughout the rest the week.\n\nGrahame Madge, Met Office forecaster, said: \"As we go into Wednesday we are going to see a weather front coming in from the west bringing rain in the north from early morning.\n\n\"This will bring showers across England through the day and as it is quite a slow moving system it will not have cleared into rush hour on Thursday when there could be some further heavy bursts of rain.\n\n\"The rest of Thursday will be largely clear although there will be showers around and some could be heavy while gales will affect northwestern coasts.\n\n\"Low pressure will still be anchored off Scotland on Friday bringing strong winds and even thunder.\"\n\nNHC\n\nCOURSE: Storm Gert is expected to track north east in the coming days\n\nBut some forecasters are hoping for better weather next week, with more settled conditions and fewer showers expected.\n\nWeatherOnline forecaster Simon Keeling said: \"Unsettled conditions are forecast in the next few days with a risk of some heavier bursts of rain.\n\n\"The weekend brings some showers in the north and west with fewer east and south.\n\n\"Next week is showing signs of conditions improving with higher pressure building to bring drier and brighter weather and turning warmer Gert is traveling 10 mph and carrying 75 mph winds. But there are no hazards to land currently.\n\nA Hurricane Gert Projected Path update today reveals the system strengthening later this week. NHC in a news update today reports that \"Gert is moving toward the north-northeast near 10 mph (17 km/h). A gradual turn toward the northeast with an increase in forward speed is expected through the next couple of days.\" NHC adds \"Maximum sustained winds are near 75 mph (120 km/h) with higher gusts. The hurricane is forecast to become a little stronger during the next day or so. Hurricane-force winds extend outward up to 25 miles (35 km) from the center and tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 105 miles (165 km).\"\n\nStrong surf is expected in North Carolina from Gert. NHC reports that \"Swells generated by Gert will spread northward along the east coast of the United States from North Carolina northward to Long Island during the next couple of days. Swells are also expected to affect Bermuda during the next couple of days.\" NHC adds that \"These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions. Atlantic storm heads this way", "uri": "710317964", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T12:46:00Z", "time": "12:46:00", "body": "Atlantic storm is moving north-east at about 21mph and is could create rip currents off New Jersey today\n\nIt's been a washout summer for parts of Britain featuring heavy rain, flooding and thunderstorms so far - but now, ironically, a hurricane could bring a change in conditions.\n\nHurricane Gert is currently spinning at 90mph near Bermuda but it is set to pull up a band of good weather for Britain as temperatures rise over the weekend to reach 81F (27C) in the South East of England by next Monday.\n\nBut the remnants of the Atlantic storm which is moving in a north-easterly direction at about 21mph could also bring 1.6in (40mm) of rain for parts of North West England and Scotland on Sunday into Monday.\n\nBoats out at sea at King Edwards Bay in Tynemouth this morning as parts of the North East witnessed a stunning sunrise\n\nA boat sails past the rising sun this morning at King Edwards Bay in Tynemouth, Tyne and Wear\n\nA satellite photograph from the NOAA and Nasa shows Hurricane Gert in the Atlantic Ocean off the US east coast overnight\n\nMet Office forecaster Nicky Maxey said: 'Gert is in the Atlantic at the moment. As it travels it's sort of going to weaken and evolve and what's left becomes subsumed by a low pressure system which is crossing the Atlantic.'\n\nShe told MailOnline: 'By the time it reaches our coast it's just a bit of warm air, and the southern half of the country is quite likely to see some fine, dry weather with some warmer temperatures.\n\n'By Sunday for the South East we could be looking at getting up to the mid-20s Celsius, and Monday quite widely mid-20s, maybe 26C, 27C with ideal conditions.\n\n'But further north overnight Sunday to Monday we've got some fairly heavy rain coming through in North West Scotland and England. This low pressure system is passing to the north of us.\n\nShe added: 'So the further north you get that wet weather - further south you get the warmth. We're not predicting that we're going to see anything unusual as far as winds are concerned.\n\nRain is expected over North West parts of Britain this afternoon (left) while today's UV index is high for many areas (right)\n\nYour browser does not support the iframe HTML tag. Try viewing this in a modern browser like Chrome, Safari, Firefox or Internet Explorer 9 or later.\n\n'With that low pressure system further north it's going to be a bit breezy but it's not going to be hurricane winds. It's still a hurricane at the moment but it will become an ex-hurricane and then it will weaken and disappear.\n\n'None of the weather coming through is going to be particularly exceptional for the time of year. It's not unusual for these systems in the western Atlantic having influence on our weather systems.'\n\nMs Maxey added that wind speeds of 40mph (35 knots) were possible on Friday into Sunday, but gusts of that strength were unlikely to be brought by the remnants of the hurricane system on Sunday.\n\nToday, Gert was churning the surf and creating a high risk for rip currents along the New Jersey shore in the US, with beachgoers advised to swim near lifeguards and told to relax and float if caught in a rip current.\n\nThe second hurricane of the season in the Atlantic is not posing a direct threat to the Jersey shore, with it turning north-east as forecasters said an increase in forward speed was expected through the next couple of days.\n\nBut swells generated by Gert will spread along the east coast of the US from North Carolina northward to New York. The storm was moving north-northeast at 10 mph.\n\nBy 5:30 p.m. Tuesday, said Carlie Buccola, of the National Weather Service based in Upton, the storm system was about 385 miles northwest of Bermuda -- but moving steadily away from the U.S. coast. No coastal watches or warnings were in effect.\n\n\"It's going to stay well off shore,\" she said. \"There's no impact whatsoever on land.\"\n\nadvertisement | advertise on {"sim": 0.572549045085907, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9113086", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "ctpost.com", "title": "CTPost", "id": "22"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "http://www.ctpost.com/img/pages/article/opengraph_default.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 948, "textEnd": 960, "date": "2012-10-", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.ctpost.com/weather/article/Active-tropical-weather-could-obscure-11817465.php", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:49:00", "title": "'Active' tropical weather could obscure eclipse", "uri": "709312750", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:49:00Z", "time": "15:49:00", "body": "While Tropical Storm Gert is not expected to make landfall, the 10-day outlook forecasts a very active tropical weather pattern that deserves watching.\n\nWhile it's too early to know what effect - if any - this weather could have on Connecticut, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says this is the time of year when hurricanes are most frequent and at their strongest. It urges coastal residents to make sure they have their hurricane preparedness plans in place and to monitor the latest forecasts.\n\nOn Monday morning, Gert was about 450 miles southwest of Bermuda. Additional strengthening is forecast and Gert is expected to become a hurricane by Tuesday night. A gradual turn toward the northeast with an increase in forward speed is forecast over the next two days.\n\nGert could cause choppy conditions in Long Island Sound later this week.\n\nThe last major tropical systems to affect Connecticut were Irene in 2011 and Sandy in October 2012.\n\nForecasters are keeping on eye on an area disturbed weather in the eastern Atlantic Ocean may develop into the next tropical depression\n\nThe National Hurricane Center says \"shower and thunderstorm activity associated with a broad trough of low pressure southwest of the Cabo Verde Islands has increased since last night. Environmental conditions are expected to be generally conducive for development of this disturbance for the next several days while it moves westward at about 15 mph over the tropical Atlantic.\"\n\nJust last week, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration forecasters updated its forecast saying there is a higher likelihood of an above-normal season.\n\n\"We're now entering the peak of the season when the bulk of the storms usually form,\" said Gerry Bell, Ph.D., lead seasonal hurricane forecaster at NOAA's Climate Prediction Center. \"The wind and air patterns in the area of the tropical Atlantic and Caribbean where many storms develop are very conducive to an above-normal season. This is in part because the chance of an El Nino forming, which tends to prevent storms from strengthening, has dropped significantly from May.\"\n\nBell noted other factors that point to an above-normal season include warmer waters across the tropical Atlantic than models previously predicted and higher predicted activity from available models.\n\nThe long range forecast is also not good news for East Coast residents may not see the first total solar eclipse in the United States since 1991. In Connecticut, about 70 percent of the sun will be obscured by the moon.\n\nParts of southeastern states like South Carolina andf Kentucky are in line for a total eclipse of the sun. But the long-range forecast calls for a 40 percent chance of precipitation at the time of the eclipse.\n\nAccuweather says eclipse viewing will be \"poor\" in Florida and the South Carolina coast and The National Hurricane Center reports that TS Gert will become Hurricane Gert overnight.\n\nThe latest Hurricane Gert Projected Path update was issued this morning by the National Hurricane Center. TS Gert will formulate into Hurricane Gert tonight. The system is 460 miles west of Bermuda traveling at 8 mph. \"There are no coastal watches or warnings in effect\", NHC reports. A further update is set for later today.\n\nGert is set to turn northward overnight. Namely \"Gert is moving toward the north near 8 mph (13 km/h). A gradual turn toward the northeast with an increase in forward speed is forecast for the next 48 h.\" NHC adds \"Maximum sustained winds have increased to near 60 mph (95 km/h) with higher gusts. Additional strengthening is forecast and Gert is expected to become a hurricane by tomorrow night. Tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 90 miles (150 km) from the center.\"\n\nHazards to land overnight include strong surf. Namely \"Swells generated by Gert will begin to affect portions of the coast of North Carolina and Virginia later today. These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions. Please consult products from your local weather office. For continued coverage of all hurricanes today click HERE. On Tuesday morning (Aug. 15), hurricane forecasters were tracking three disturbances in the Atlantic Ocean, in addition to Hurricane Gert.\n\nTwo of the three disturbances have a low chance of developing into at least a tropical depression. However, one low pressure system has a medium chance (40 percent) of becoming a full-blown storm.\n\nAccording to the National Hurricane Center, the system with the most potential for developing is an elongated area of low pressure more than a thousand miles east of the Lesser Antilles. The system was expected to move west at 15 to 20 mph across the tropical Atlantic Ocean, crossing into the Caribbean Sea on Friday.\n\nForecasters say environmental conditions appear \"somewhat supportive\" of tropical cyclone formation over the next few days but should become less favorable once the system moves into the Caribbean Sea.\n\nForecasters also were tracking a second area of low pressure, associated with a tropical wave, that was a few hundred miles southwest of the Cabo Verde Islands. Environmental conditions could be conducive for some slow development of the system over the next few days while it moves west at 15 to 20 mph.\n\nAnd finally, forecasters were keeping tabs on a tropical wave over western Africa that was expected to emerge over the far eastern Atlantic Ocean on Wednesday. Conditions appear conducive for some development after that time while the wave moves west at about 15 mph.\n\nRead the full advisory.\n\nMeanwhile, Hurricane Gert on Tuesday morning was generating swells that forecasters say will spread along the East Coast of the U.S., and will also affect Bermuda. The storm is not expected to hit land. As Hurricane Gert moves NE this week, it is going to bump into the jet stream.\n\n'This is going to cause the jet stream to ripple around more, which will bring a change in the weather pattern affecting the UK.\n\n'Gert is expected to push NorthEast this week, before weakening as it moves over cooler water.\n\nHurricane Gert will bump into the jet stream and may bring summer weather back to UK. NO significant impacts for NE Fl./SE Ga.....\n\nT.D. #8 has strengthened into tropical storm \"Gert\" with satellite data showing decent outflow in the upper levels + some banding features at the surface. No change in the expected sharp turn to the north then northeast thanks to a weak but still significant upper level trough + surface cold front along the east coast of the U.S. This set-up will keep the tropical cyclone well to the east of Jacksonville/Fl. & the entire U.S. coastline + well to the west & north of Bermuda.\n\nThere will be a bit of an uptick in wave action & rip current risk early in the upcoming week from Florida to Chesapeake Bay.\n\nEast Atlantic -- tropical waves marching west off Africa are looking rather impressive as we head into the peak of the Cabo (Cape) Verde season. There will be a good chance for multiple areas of concern / possible development over the next 1 - 3 weeks.\n\nA telling map below -- the Velocity Potential Anomalies -- shows widespread & strong \"upward\" vertical motion over much of the Atlantic Basin. This kind of pattern often correlates with an increase in tropical activity. I would not be at all surprised to see several named storms develop over the Atlantic Basin within the next couple of weeks. As we head toward the peak of the hurricane season, one should always be prepared!\n\nWind shear analysis (red is stronger shear) (increasing shear in the 2-4 days path of '99L':\n\nImagery below courtesy CIMMS shows African Saharan dust (orange & red):\n\nSE U.S. surface map.... the front to the north of Jacksonville is the surface reflection of the upper level trough that is turning \"Gert\" north then northeast well out over the W. On the forecast track, Harvey should move through the Windward Island and into the eastern Caribbean Sea on Friday.\n\nThere is a general agreement among different models to drive Harvey directly to the west maintaining the system south of a large pool of drier air, while squeezing it between two regions of strong wind shear to the north and south.\n\nSea surface temperatures are high enough to feed the storm with plenty of energy. In fact, the entire region is experiencing positive water temperature anomalies, which favour further storm development.\n\nWhat happens beyond the weekend is still up in the air, although model predictions point towards a track that could very well intensify the storm into a hurricane before reaching land in Central America anywhere from Nicaragua to Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula.\n\nJust over 800 km to the east-northeast of 91L, 92L continues to show signs of organization, as it continues to move west-northwest at 25-30 km/h.\n\nAs 92L moves north of the Leeward Islands beyond the weekend, it is expected to encounter stronger mid to upper level winds in the atmosphere, which would slow down the storm's development.\n\nBeyond this point, models tend to deviate in their predicted track. Some drive the potential storm closer to Puerto Rico and the northern coast of the Dominican Republic, while others take it about 300 to nearly 500 km to the north of those two locations straight to the Bahamas, and eventually into southern Florida.\n\nWe will monitor closely this evolution and update the expected track beyond the weekend as new model data comes in.\n\nThe third potential storm of this tropical Atlantic trio is holding its position near the African coast of Guinea. Very little change in this cluster of thunderstorms has occurred over the past 24 hours. However, the National Hurricane Center is anticipating that some gradual development is expected as the system begins to move to the west-northwest over the next few days.", "date": "2017-08-17", Forecasters gave all three systems a 40 percent chance of becoming tropical cyclones over the next five days.\n\nHurricane Gert, which swept off the U.S. coast this week, continued its trek to the north Atlantic. The compact storm intensified slightly, with sustained winds of 90 mph, and will likely continue to gain strength today before it weakens tomorrow, forecasters said. It will also likely pick up speed as it continues rolling to the northeast.\n\nWednesday morning Gert was located about 330 miles northwest of Bermuda.\n\nHistorically, hurricane season peaks during late to mid September when conditions are generally more favorable for more intense storms. Last month, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration nudged up its forecast for the season after concluding the tropical Atlantic and Caribbean were likely setting the stage for more hurricanes.\n\nThey now expect the season to produce 14 to 19 named storms, five to nine hurricanes and two to five major hurricanes with winds topping 110 mph.", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": Maximum sustained winds were at 75 mph.\n\nGert was moving north at 12 mph. A turn toward the northeast is expected later today.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Gert could gather strength later today or Wednesday.\n\nMore: 2017 hurricane season could be most active since 2010\n\nSwells from Gert will impact Bermuda and the east coast from North Carolina north to Long Island over the next couple of days.\n\nNext advisory will be issued at 11 a.m.\n\nAlso in the Atlantic\n\nThe National Hurricane Center is now monitoring three other systems farther east in the Atlantic.\n\nAn elongated area of low pressure located more than a thousand miles east of the Lesser Antilles is producing disorganized showers and thunderstorms.\n\nA look at #91L and likely 92L southwest of the Cabo Verde Islands on GOES16 this morning. and development, if any, should be slow to occur while the system moves slowly west.\n\nFormation chance through 48 hours: near 0 percent.Formation chance through 5 days: 10 percent.\n\nA {"sim": 0.5058823823928833, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9100593", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "twcnews.com", "title": "TWC News", "id": "9476"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "http://s7d2.scene7.com/is/image/TWCNews/wxweb081417a_jpg?wid=640", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.twcnews.com/nc/triangle-sandhills/weather/2017/08/14/no-issues-expected-from-tropical-storm-gert-in-the-carolinas.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:42:00", "title": "No issues expected from Tropical Storm Gert in the Carolinas", "uri": "709281539", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T10:01:00Z", "time": "10:01:00", "body": "Tropical Storm Gert is expected to gain strength over the next day or two as it passes between the Carolina coast and Bermuda. The National Hurricane Center forecasts the storm to briefly become a category one hurricane by late Tuesday or early Wednesday. Eventually, the storm will weaken by the end of the week in the cooler waters of the northern Atlantic.\n\nGert's path will keep the storm far enough off the Carolina coast that it will not impact our weather.\n\nScattered storms will still be possible across North Carolina though. An unsettled weather pattern that is not at all related to the tropical storm will make for an active radar most afternoons this week.\n\nMuch of the state should see at least one to two inches of rain over the next week. The turn to the N/NW then north is underway thanks to a weak but still significant upper level trough + surface cold front along the east coast of the U.S. This set-up will keep the tropical cyclone well to the east of Jacksonville/Fl. & the entire U.S. coastline + well to the west & north of Bermuda later this week.\n\nThere will be a bit of an uptick in wave action (an easterly swell) & rip current risk into Tue. for coastal Florida & SE Ga.... with a more significant increase from the SC coast to Chesapeake Bay for midweek.\n\n\"Gert\" will reach Jacksonville latitude by Mon. afternoon.... about midway between the NC coast & Bermuda by Tue. morning & then accelerating northeast over the open N. Atlantic for the rest of the week where rapid weakening will occur due to cool sea surface water + increasing shear. It is quite possible, however, that \"Gert\" will attain hurricane strength before reaching these hostile conditions.\n\n3-4 foot breakers at First Coast beaches into early Tue. but the much higher seas will stay well offshore....\n\nMeanwhile.... a large but disorganized area of \"disturbed\" weather ('91L') is over the Eastern Atlantic. Overall conditions are expected to be favorable for the development of a tropical cyclone this week over the Central Atlantic. Forecast models vary widely on location, intensity & movement by the weekend into next week on what could become \"Harvey\". At this point, I favor a more westward move (strengthening Bermuda high over Central/N. Atlantic) on what will likely be a slowly developing system. Stay tuned!\n\nEast Atlantic -- tropical waves marching west off Africa are looking rather impressive as we head into the peak of the Cabo (Cape) Verde season. There will be a good chance for multiple areas of concern / possible development over the next 1 - 3 weeks.... including what may very well be \"Harvey\" approaching the SW Atlantic by this weekend.\n\nAdding fuel to the fire of a possible iminent uptick in activity over the tropical Atlantic: a telling map below -- the Velocity Potential Anomalies -- shows widespread & strong \"upward\" vertical motion over much of the Atlantic Basin. This kind of pattern often correlates with an increase in tropical activity. "http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/hurricane-gert-waves-storm-rip-currents-coast-1.4247725", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:01:00", "title": "Hurricane Gert to produce big swells and rip currents along N.S. coast", "uri": "709880944", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T17:01:00Z", "time": "17:01:00", "body": "Stormier than usual Atlantic hurricane season expected this year\n\nEnvironment Canada is advising swimmers and people in small boats to stay out of Atlantic coastal waters off Nova Scotia on Wednesday and Thursday while Hurricane Gert churns through the area.\n\nHurricane Gert, currently west of Bermuda and packing winds of up to 120 kilometres per hour, is forecasted to move east toward Newfoundland and south of the Grand Banks.\n\nIt won't make landfall along the Eastern Seaboard but the Atlantic coast will experience swells as Gert moves toward the North Atlantic.\n\nThose swells will produce two-to-three-metre waves and rip currents, beginning Wednesday in the southwest region of Nova Scotia and spreading east to Cape Breton in the afternoon, Environment Canada said in a special weather statement Tuesday.\n\nThose conditions will gradually diminish Thursday into Friday, from west to east, Environment Canada meteorologist Linda Libby said.\n\n\"Any time we get rip currents forming, it is certainly hazardous to people who are in the water and even possibly for those who are boating, especially those who are not familiar with the local water,\" she said.\n\nThey are in danger of \"being pulled offshore very quickly and certainly if you are in the water, possibly to very negative results. Particularly if you are not a strong swimmer and don't know what to do when caught in a rip current,\" Libby said.\n\n\"It is probably not the best time to be entering the water.\"\n\nThat message is going out to people along the Atlantic coastline of the United States as well, she added.\n\n\"It is a very significant hazard even though the tropical system, in this case Hurricane Gert, is offshore.\"\n\nLibby recommends tourists and locals explore other options for recreation while the weather system is passing by. It should be clear by Friday, she said.\n\nResidents and visitors to the Atlantic provinces should also prepare for more of this type of weather in the coming weeks.\n\n\"Unfortunately, it has moved into the more active part of the hurricane season for our part of the Atlantic. We start to see more tropical disturbances that potentially become tropical storms or hurricanes,\" Libby said.\n\n\"We really want locals and visitors to be more aware at this time of the hurricane season, kind of check in with the weather a little more frequently. August 12, has sustained maximum winds of 65 kilometers per hour (40 m / h) and maintains its location east of the Florida coast, in a path that according to meteorologists will keep it away from the mainland US.\n\nAccording to the NHC's evening bulletin, the storm moves at 17 kilometers per hour (10 m / h) and with a northeasterly direction, a general movement that has continued throughout the day and then has taken a turn towards the North the night of Sunday August 13.\n\nThe Miami-based weather center predicted a \"slow strengthening\" of this cyclone between Monday and Tuesday.\n\nThe {"sim": 0.4941176474094391, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9114986", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "foxnews.com", "title": "Fox News", "id": "71"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "http://www.foxnews.com/content/dam/fox-news/logo/og-fn-foxnews.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.foxnews.com/us/2017/08/14/uptick-in-atlantic-tropical-systems-may-continue-as-new-feature-bears-watching.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:00:00", "title": "Uptick in Atlantic tropical systems may continue as new feature bears watching", "uri": "709317555", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T16:00:00Z", "time": "16:00:00", "body": "In the wake of Gert, another batch of thunderstorms over the central Atlantic Ocean has the potential to develop into a tropical depression and storm this week.\n\nGert will turn away from North America but has potential to become the second hurricane of the 2017 Atlantic season.\n\nThousands of miles farther to the southeast, a plume of moisture continues to grow westward from Africa to the south-central Atlantic.\n\nInterests from the northern islands of the Caribbean to the Bahamas and coastal areas in the southeastern and south-central United States may want to monitor the progress of this area of disturbed weather.\n\nMost of the inhibitive dust, dry air and strong westerly winds aloft may remain north of the path of the area of concern through this week.\n\n\"There is the potential for this large area of moisture to spawn a tropical depression or storm this week and perhaps as early as Wednesday,\" according to AccuWeather Hurricane Expert Dan Kottlowski.\n\nPart of this moisture plume was responsible for producing flash flooding and mudslides in Sierra Leone at the start of this week. Hundreds were killed, according to the Associated Press.\n\nAs is often the case this time of the year, \"the area of disturbed weather will move in a general west or slightly north of west path this week,\" Kottlowski said. \"This may bring the feature close to the Leeward Islands this weekend.\"\n\nUntil the feature develops, future paths of movement this weekend may be very misleading and used with caution at this point, Kottlowski stated.\n\nThere are a number of factors that could pull the feature to the north on a path similar to Gert or allow a more westward track over the northern Caribbean and perhaps into the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nThe difference with the setup for Gert versus this new feature is that a path into the Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico was not a significant options for Gert.\n\nThe strength of the feature, geography and the position of other weather systems over the eastern United States and the Atlantic Ocean by next week are at the top of this list of factors that may affect movement.\n\nFor example, a weak feature may have a greater chance of staying on a westerly course for a longer period of time. A well-developed feature, such as a tropical storm or hurricane, may have a greater chance of taking a curved path to the northwest and north much sooner.\n\nMost westward-moving, well-developed tropical systems tend to pass to the north or south of the Greater Antilles, due to the mountainous terrain.\n\nMore information on the path and strength of this new feature will become available as but it could be threatened by a Bristolian-sounding weather system.\n\nTropical Storm Gert, which is currently brewing over the Atlantic, could ruin hopes of a summer weekend as it could bring in a low pressure system causing a continuation of blustery showers.\n\nThe naming of tropical storms involves a strict procedure set up by the World Meteorological Organisation, but Storm Gert shares its name with the classic Bristolian word.\n\n'Gert', as seen in the high-praise phrase 'gert lush', translates into Queen's English as 'big' or 'very'.\n\nHowever, there is controversy about the correct spelling of 'gert' in Bristol as it has traditionally been spelled as 'gurt'.\n\nSunshine and warmer weather has not been completely ruled out for most of the British Isles, but forecaster Hannah Findley, of The Weather Channel , said confidence in forecasts for the upcoming week was low because of the possible impact of Tropical Storm Gert.\n\nAn area of low pressure will absorb the worst of the storm as it moves towards the UK - hopefully leaving the way clear for higher pressure to take charge.\n\nAfter this low pressure passes, there will be an area of high pressure over the UK from the middle of next week. Differing forecast models dispute the effect it will have on the country's weather.\n\nSome predictions indicate the high will be filled with warm tropical air, while other options go for cooler conditions with temperatures and rainfall around normal for the time of year, although this could still change.\n\nTemperatures in Bristol this weekend are expected to stick at around 19 or 20 {"sim": 0.4588235318660736, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9369247", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "enn.com", "title": "enn.com", "id": "3906"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 444, "textEnd": 459, "date": "2017-08-14", "freq": 2, "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.enn.com/sci-tech/article/52161", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:36:00", "title": "NASA's GPM Found Gert Strengthening into a Hurricane", "uri": "710009733", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T22:36:00Z", "time": "22:36:00", "body": "NASA looked at the rainfall rates within Tropical Storm Gert as it continued to strengthen and found the most intense rainfall on the tropical cyclone's eastern side. Just over 12 hours later, Gert would strengthen into a hurricane. As Gert has strengthened, the storm began generating dangerous surf along the U.S. East coast.\n\nThe Global Precipitation Measurement mission or GPM core observatory satellite passed above tropical storm Gert on August 14, 2017 at 9:36 a.m. EDT (1336 UTC) when winds had reached about 57.5 mph (50 knots). Data collected by GPM's Microwave Imager (GMI) and Dual-Frequency Precipitation Radar (DPR) instruments were used to show the coverage and the intensity of rainfall around Tropical Storm Gert. The area covered by GPM's radar swath revealed that the most intense rainfall, measuring greater 3.5 inches (90 mm) per hour, was located in bands of rain on the eastern side of the storm.\n\nThat GPM pass was mentioned in a National Hurricane Center (NHC) Tropical Storm Gert Discussion that noted, \"A recent 1336 UTC (9:36 a.m. EDT) GMI overpass shows a large band of convection wrapping around the circulation ...\"\n\nAt NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, GPM's Radar (DPR Ku Band) data was used to create a 3-D cross-section view through Gert. This examination of the storm's 3-D precipitation structure showed that the tallest thunderstorms were located in an intense band of rain east of Gert's center. The tall thunderstorms in that band were shown by DPR to reach altitudes above 9.4 miles (15.2 km). GPM is a joint mission between NASA and the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, JAXA.\n\nContinue reading at NASA / Goddard Space Flight Center\n\nImage: The GPM core observatory satellite passed above tropical storm Gert on August 14 at 9:36 a.m. EDT (1336 UTC) and found the most intense rainfall, measuring greater 3.5 inches (90 mm) per hour on the eastern side of the storm. The tall thunderstorms in that area reached altitudes above 9.4 miles (15.2 km). The Energy Report 08/18/17", "uri": "711475701", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T13:48:00Z", "time": "13:48:00", "body": "The despicable and horrendous terror attacks in Barcelona Spain are being felt by global markets that are sinking because of the lack of respect and tolerance for our fellow-man. We need to debate or points of view with intellect and respect not with mobs, protests and violence and hate.\n\nOil prices are rising after Genscape reported that supplies in Cushing, Oklahoma suddenly plunged by one million barrels. This is adding to the perception that the physical oil market is tightening much faster. Brent spreads driving the market into contango is signaling that demand is exceeding short-term supply. Historic draws in US inventories are signaling the same thing. Oil supply in the US is back below 2016 levels.\n\nSupplies should tighten even more as US crude imports, especially heavy crude, could be retrained by politics and Mother Nature. Reuters is reporting that a tanker carrying a cargo of about 1.0 million barrels of Venezuelan heavy crude has been stranded for more than a month off the coast of Louisiana for lack of a bank letter of credit to discharge. The cargo's fate adds to state-run oil company PDVSA's precarious financial position. Revenue from the company's oil sales, which have suffered because of low prices and declining production, account for more than 90 percent of the nation's exports.\n\nReuters says that major banks are cutting exposure to Venezuela as a result of political upheaval in the South American country. Some have closed accounts linked to officials of the OPEC member who have had sanctions leveled against them by the U.S. government and have refused to provide correspondent bank services or trade in government bonds. Signs of supply tightness have started appearing in the United States, the world's biggest oil consumer.\n\nThe Atlantic Is more active from a storm perspective than we have seen in some time. Tropical Storm Harvey has formed and there are two storms right behind them. Accu Weather says that from west to east, the systems have been dubbed Tropical Storm Harvey and 92 L. The third system is likely to be 93 L. Accu Weather says that designation is assigned between 90 and 99, when there is potential for the formation of a tropical depression or storm within several days. The \"L\" represents the potential formation for the Atlantic Ocean. Interests in the Caribbean and Central America should closely monitor the tropical Atlantic, particularly shipping, cruise and fishing ventures.\n\nTropical Storm Harvey to enter Caribbean Sea this weekend. Accu Weather says that the storm developed on Thursday afternoon east of the Windward Islands, becoming the eighth named tropical system of the 2017 Atlantic season. Heavy, gusty thunderstorms from Harvey will affect the Windward and southern Leeward Islands through Friday. Enough rain can fall on the islands to cause flash flooding and mudslides. Wind gusts can be strong enough to cause minor property damage. Small craft should stay in port on Friday.\n\nThen 92 L may pass north of the Caribbean Sea next week, the steering winds are likely to guide the second area of disturbed weather farther north than Harvey. \"We project 92 L to pass over or just north of the Leeward Islands this weekend,\" according to AccuWeather Hurricane Expert Dan Kottlowski. How much strengthening occurs will determine the intensity of rainfall, winds and seas. Some dry air has become drawn into 92 L, which could hinder its development for a time. \"If 92 L can overcome the dry air, it has a chance at becoming a depression or tropical storm this weekend,\" Kottlowski said. A track just north of the islands of the northern Caribbean, especially the mountainous islands of Puerto Rico, Hispaniola and Cuba, would favor development and strengthening, as opposed to a track right over the islands. So 92 could pose the most threat to the Gulf of Mexico shipping lanes. The third storm is expected at this time to turn out to sea and pose little risk to land.\n\nGoing south to Texas. {"sim": 0.4470588266849518, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3358582", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9089661", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "nola.com", "title": "NOLA.com", "id": "2072"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3358582", "image": "http://image.nola.com/home/nola-media/width620/img/hurricane_impact/photo/23229496-standard.png", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.nola.com/hurricane/index.ssf/2017/08/weather_disturbance_atlantic.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:44:00", "title": "Hurricane forecasters tracking disturbance in Atlantic", "uri": "709253468", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T13:44:00Z", "time": "13:44:00", "body": "A weather disturbance in the Atlantic has a medium chance (60 percent) of developing into at least a tropical depression in the next five days, according to forecasters with the National Hurricane Center.\n\nIn a Monday morning update, forecasters said the broad trough of low pressure is southwest of the Cabo Verde Islands. Showers and thunderstorm activity associated with the disturbance has increased since Sunday night.\n\nIt's moving west at 15 mph over the Atlantic and forecasters said environmental conditions are expected to be generally conducive for development of this disturbance for the next several days. Read more.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are tracking Tropical Storm Gert, which is in the Atlantic off the East Coast. but there could be some violent weather first.\n\nThere was early confusion among forecasters about how badly Britain's weather would be affected by the hurricane that formed earlier this week in the south Atlantic.\n\nEarly signs pointed to the storm being unleashed over the UK from this weekend but the Weather Channel - along with amateur Derby weather watcher Robert Shaw - is now predicting better weather from the weekend onwards.\n\nMr Shaw from Chellaston said Sunday is \"likely to be hot\" and while next week might not be baking there will be more \"dry, bright and sunny weather\".\n\nThe latest predictions indicate Hurricane Gert could now lure stubborn low pressure away from the north of Scotland, allowing highs from the south-west to take charge of the UK's weather.\n\nRead More Things to do in and around Derbyshire\n\nThe hurricane is set to fizzle out as it crosses the Atlantic allowing a ridge of high pressure to take charge bringing some pleasant weather for much of the UK.\n\nRemnants of Gert will then be swallowed up by the low creating the opening for the ridge of high pressure.\n\nThe Weather Channel confirmed the remnants of Gert would merge with a low from Canada to head north-west of the UK on Sunday with the worst of the weather heading north.\n\nBefore then, there will be some quite potent weather for parts of the UK with very heavy rain and high winds in the north-west.
